content.description:
Properties of <math alttext="C H 3 O H" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></math> are given in the table. A student is given a beaker containing a solution of <math alttext="C H 3 O H liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mo>(</mo> <mi>l</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

Substance
 Boiling Point <math alttext="in degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Molar Mass <math alttext="in grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>g/mol)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="K sub a" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>

<math alttext="C H 3 O H" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></math>
 <math alttext="65" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>65</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="32.04" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>32.04</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="5.0 times 10 to the negative 16" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></math>
 <math alttext="100" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="18.02" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>18.02</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="1.0 times 10 to the negative 14" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: If the student wishes to separate and collect the two components of the solution, which of the following experimental techniques would be most appropriate?

choices.label: Using paper chromatography and collecting the liquid that first moves to the top of the paper

Combusting the <math alttext="C H 3 O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and collecting the products of the reaction
Boiling the mixture and condensing and collecting the first vapors produced
Titrating the mixture with <math alttext="H C l aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to the equivalence point

content.answer: Boiling the mixture and condensing and collecting the first vapors produced

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
